instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.LP8548: What is LP8548? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight (in very rare cases it's present like 1 time of 20)
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V (on pin1 of J8300)
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> - 5V

Tested with 3 displays.
replaced LVDS connector.
replaced <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
tested resistors on <SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> - good.

I'll appriacate any solutions to test, thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message:
Looks too high.
Did you try compatible full LCD assembly (including video cable)?
Try with broken screen, is more easy to detect backlight presence.

Do you really get image on internal LCD?
eDP data lines problem can keep screen black.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message:
two lcd are broken, but backlight working and tested on other board:/ (they still includes cable)
Every startup I see apple logo with the lamp.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message:
Do you get 48V at pin 1 of J8300?
If yes, change LCD connector.

Compare voltage with an working board; should be aprox 39V, I think.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message: Usually I get 38/39V at pin1 of J8300 lcd connector with working backlight on other macbooks <CHIP>LP8548</CHIP> driver series. I?ve already replaced the lcd connector. Maybe it?s something small I?m missing:(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message: Bad screen, bad screen cable, or bad LCD connector. You 100% MUST use a 2015 screen 2013/14 will NOT work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message:
Thanks JohnB8812! I checked the screens I was testing and all of then were 2013/14. Even customer's screen on 2015 macbook pro was from 2013/14. That was tricky. Got another macbook pro 2015 and that screen worled just fine.
Is there any solutions to make 2013/14 screen to make working on 2015 board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 48V
threads.message: Nope have to have the correct screen for these no workaround
